name: OCaml
title: The [OCaml](https://www.ocaml.org/) cheat sheet is a one-page reference sheet for the OCaml programming language.

cards.title: Intro
cards.body: The [OCaml](https://www.ocaml.org/) cheat sheet is a one-page reference sheet for the OCaml programming language.

cards.title: hello.ml
hello.ml
cards.code:
$ ocamlc -o hello.byte hello.ml
$ ./hello.byte

cards.title: hello.ml
cards.code:
$ dune build hello.exe
$ _build/default/hello.exe

# you can also just run
$ dune exec ./hello.exe

cards.title: hello.ml
cards.body: See the [dune](https://dune.build/) documentation for more info.

cards.title: Imports
cards.code: $ opam install hex

cards.title: Imports
cards.code: open Hex

cards.title: Imports
cards.code:
Hex.of_string "hex string"

let open Hex in
  of_string "to hex"

cards.title: Comments
cards.code:
(* A single line comment *)

(* A multi-line comment
* where we want to explain
* something complex *)

(* Outer comment
   (* Nested comment *)
   End of outer comment *)

cards.title: Comments
cards.code:
val sum : int -> int -> int
(** [sum x y] returns the sum
 of two integers [x] and [y] *)

cards.title: Predefined Types
cards.body: Note: `#` Indicates execution at the toplevel followed by the output

cards.title: Predefined Types
cards.code:
# ();; (* equivalent to void in C *)
- : unit = ()

cards.title: Predefined Types
cards.code:
# 5 ;; (* integer *)
- : int = 5

# 3.14 ;;  (* float *)
- : float = 3.14

# true ;; (* bool *)
- : bool = true

# false ;;
- : bool = false

# 'a' ;; (* char *)
- : char = 'a'

# "a string" ;; (* string *)
- : string = "a string"

# String.to_bytes "hello" ;; (* bytes *)
- : bytes = Bytes.of_string "hello"

# (3, 5);; (* tuple *)
- : int * int = (3, 5)

# ref 0;; (* reference *)
- : int ref = {contents = 0}

cards.title: Predefined Types
Arrays & Lists
cards.code:
# [|0; 1; 2; 3|];; (* create an array *)
- : int array = [|0; 1; 2; 3|]

# [|'u'; 's'; 'c'|].(1);; (* array access *)
- char = 's'

cards.title: Arrays & Lists
Arrays & Lists
cards.code:
# let lst = [1; 2; 3];;
- : int list = [1; 2; 3]

# let new_lst =  0 :: lst;; (* prepend to a new list *)
- : int list = [0; 1; 2; 3]

# new_lst @ [4;5;6];; (* combine two lists *)
- : int list = [0; 1; 2; 3; 4; 5; 6]

cards.title: User-Defined Types
User-Defined Types
cards.code:
type shape =
  | Circle of float
  | Rectangle of float * float

# let my_shape = Circle 5.0;;
- : shape = Circle 5.

cards.title: User-Defined Types
cards.body: Provide meaningful name to complex or commonly used types

cards.title: User-Defined Types
Functions
Functions
Functions
Recursive Functions
cards.body: All recusive functions use the rec keyword

cards.title: Recursive Functions
cards.code:
let rec factorial n =
  if n < 1 then 1 else n * factorial (n - 1)

cards.title: Recursive Functions
cards.body: Makes use of a helper function and the acc argument.

cards.title: Recursive Functions
Recursive Functions
cards.body: Notice the last call is the recursive function.

cards.title: Recursive Functions
cards.code: let factorial n = factorial_helper n 1

cards.title: Chaining
cards.body: Read from right to left, the first operation is `sum 2 3`

cards.title: Chaining
Chaining
cards.code:
(* find log((x + y)!) *)
# sum 2 3
  |> factorial
  |> float_of_int
  |> log ;;
- : float = 4.787...

cards.title: Chaining
cards.body: `|>` takes the output of the function and passes it as input to the next function in the pipeline

cards.title: If Statements
cards.code:
let is_pos x =
  if x > 0 then "positive" else "negative"

cards.title: If Statements
cards.code:
let f x =
  if x > 3 then "gt 3"
  else if x < 3 then "lt 3"
  else "eq 3"

cards.title: If Statements
cards.code:
let is_pos x =
  match x > 0 with
  | true  -> "positive"
  | false -> "negative"

cards.title: Loops
cards.code:
for i = 1 to 5 do
  print_int i
done

cards.title: Loops
cards.body: Notice the `ref` is needed to have the while condition eventually become false.

cards.title: Loops
cards.code:
let i = ref 0 in
  while !i < 5 do
    print_int !i;
    i := !i + 1
  done

cards.title: Operators
cards.code:
=         (* equal to *)
<>        (* not equal to *)
>         (* greater than *)
<         (* less than *)
>=        (* greater than or eq to *)
<=        (* less than or eq to *)

cards.title: Operators
cards.code:
(* int operator   float operator *)
+                 +.  (* addition *)
-                 -.  (* subtraction *)
*                 *.  (* multiplication *)
/                 /.  (* division *)
                  **  (* power *)

cards.title: List
List
cards.code:
(* Loop over list and apply fun f *)
List.iter f lst

(* map a function to each elem *)
(* Ex. double each element x in lst *)
List.map (fun x -> x + x) lst

(* Apply an operator between elements *)
(* Ex. 1 + 2 + 3 *)
List.fold_left (+) 0 lst

cards.title: Associaton Lists
Associaton Lists
Associaton Lists
cards.body: Association lists are similar to dictionaries or hashmaps

cards.title: Hash Tables
Hash Tables
Maps
cards.body: Maps are immutable key-value association tables.

cards.title: Maps
Maps
Maps
cards.body: Creates a new map since maps are immutable

cards.title: Maps
cards.code:
let more_books = books
  |> StringMap.add "Foundation" ("Isaac Asimov", 1951)

let less_books =
  |> StringMap.remove "Dune"

cards.title: Maps
Maps
